ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed insight into character writing and narrative styles.
Learned a lot mostly from the workshop portion of this class learned so much from my peers stories and also from the very detailed feedback Michael & peers gave me on my story

I broadened my horizons as a reader by studying short stories across a variety of authors, genres, and eras and improved my fiction writing ability via weekly writing exercises and a final short story project. I also strengthened my skills as a critic by doing line edits and giving general feedback on my peers work.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The discussion and workshop format is very strong. It could be improved by including more speculative fiction in the syllabus.

Strengths; this class created a very warm and supportive Writing environment in which taking risks was encouraged, honestly Can be hard to find at Yale so Im very grateful I found this class! The syllabus was beautifully crafted with a ton of diversity in eras/style of writing as well as identities of writers. 
Weaknesses: wish this class had a stronger workshop component earlier on, I wish Id been able to work on one consistent project throughout rather than pivoting abruptly

Strengths: you get to read an array of diverse, exciting, and thought-provoking stories; the weekly writing assignments are flexible, fun, and helpful without being tedious or taking up too much time; you receive a wealth of useful feedback from your classmates
Weaknesses: nothing in particular jumps out, but be aware that the last three weeks of the class (when it turns into a writing workshop) will require significantly more work than the previous weeks

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The format transferred well to Zoom.
All worked, especially the break, although I do question whether a seminar this long can work in an online format at all (maybe it just shouldve been shortened)

The seminar format of this course allowed us to remain engaged with the material and with each other, even though we weren't in the same room. We all shared and commented upon each other's work via email as well as during Zoom meetings, so I didn't feel that anything was lost in the COVID haze.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this course to another student.
I would highly recommend this course, it was a great introduction to reading and writing function

Yes, great class, super kind students and professor, very warm and supportive environment, great syllabus if you want to read short stories and gives you the opportunity to produce a short story youre proud of. I will say you should be aware that much of this class feels more like a reading seminar and less like a workshop class, and also that the advice you get on writing isnt particularly formalized but rather more casual.

Yes! This class is a joy for anyone who enjoys fiction writingI discovered some of my new favorite authors via the assigned stories; received kind, constructive, detailed feedback on my work; and had the immense pleasure of getting to know my fellow students as both writers and individuals as we exchanged pieces.

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
